perturbation.original_text: 12. "Purchase Order" means any of the following (a) a written purchase order issued to the Company by third party buyers for the purchase of certain Products; (b) a written purchase order issued by the Company to a Supplier for a quantity of the Product.
perturbation.changed_text: 12. "Purchase Order" means any of the following (a) an informal request issued to the Company by third party buyers for the purchase of certain Products; (b) a suggestion issued by the Company to a Supplier for a possible quantity of the Product.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Purchase Order" clearly specifies a "written purchase order," implying a legally binding document. By changing "written purchase order" to "informal request" and "suggestion," the definition now contradicts the standard legal understanding of a purchase order as a binding commitment. This introduces uncertainty regarding the enforceability of obligations based on these 'purchase orders.'

perturbation.original_text: 5. "Intellectual Property Rights" means all rights in and to (a) U.S. and foreign patents and patent applications, including all divisions, substitutions, continuations, continuations-in-part, and any reissues, re-examinations and extensions thereof, (b) copyrights and other rights in works of authorship, (c) unpatented inventions, trade secrets, data, processes, or materials, (d) mask work rights, and (e) other intellectual property or proprietary rights of any kind now known or hereafter recognized in any jurisdiction, but excluding trademarks, service marks, trade names, trade dress, domain names, logos and similar rights, and the goodwill associated therewith.
perturbation.changed_text: 5. "Intellectual Property Rights" means some rights in and to (a) U.S. and foreign patents and patent applications, including all divisions, substitutions, continuations, continuations-in-part, and any reissues, re-examinations and extensions thereof, (b) copyrights and other rights in works of authorship, (c) unpatented inventions, trade secrets, data, processes, or materials, (d) mask work rights, and (e) other intellectual property or proprietary rights of any kind now known or hereafter recognized in any jurisdiction, but excluding trademarks, service marks, trade names, trade dress, domain names, logos and similar rights, and the goodwill associated therewith.
perturbation.explanation: By changing "all rights" to "some rights", the definition of intellectual property rights becomes ambiguous. This directly contradicts established intellectual property law, which clearly defines the scope and nature of these rights. This creates uncertainty as to what protections are actually covered and enforceable under the contract, impacting the indemnification clauses related to intellectual property infringement.

perturbation.original_text: 3. "Delivery Term" means DDP (Incoterms 2010) at delivery point in China. The Delivery Term may be otherwise determined by the Company and the Supplier in the Purchase Order where delivery point is other place than China.
perturbation.changed_text: 3. "Delivery Term" means whenever the product will be shipped. The Delivery Term may be otherwise determined by the Company and the Supplier in the Purchase Order where delivery point is other place than China.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing the specific Incoterms 2010 definition (DDP) with the vague term "whenever the product will be shipped" introduces significant ambiguity. Incoterms are a globally recognized standard set of trade terms. This contradicts the established meaning of "Delivery Term" under international commercial law. This change creates uncertainty and enforceability issues, particularly concerning risk of loss and responsibility for shipping costs.
